title: [恐懼撚收皮]病毒變種 只會增加傳播 降低致命或其他毒性 係常識黎

replies.msg:
恐懼撚入面係咪無人讀過生物或者常識
病毒係為左複製自己存在
如果殺死個host / 令host 壽命降低會令病毒傳播唔到
所以病毒突變/進化只會增加傳染力同時降低殺傷力 (廢炎本身已好低殺傷力)
傳媒大肆宣傳病毒變種 只講傳播力增加只係報導一半嘅事實 意圖散播恐懼
精神病黃絲恐懼撚係咪完全無人讀過生物或者理科?

replies.msg:
你憑咩去確定一隻病毒就「技能點得咁多」？
你確定普通水痘同埋黑死病嘅「點數」真係相同？


再加上，病毒根本無辦法決定點樣變種
每一次變種都係隨機過程。以人類觀察可以得知病毒變種之後傳播，致命係強咗定係弱咗。但係你點樣確定每一次變種對病毒都係好事？

就算喺演化角度，變種都唔係次次都係好事啦，棕熊變種變做北極熊，都係經歷過幾多百萬次變得更加差嘅變種例如冇咗隻腳，甩晒啲皮等，先至去到而家嘅北極熊

而且，變種病毒到而家只係傳播咗四個幾月，用咁短嘅時間真係確定到佢真係較強？你唔俾佢好似鬱金香or蝗蟲咁樣只係泡沫？

我哋只係人類，病毒演化（對病毒自己）有冇利益，於病毒係咪有利，根本唔重要。我哋在乎嘅只有佢咁樣變異只係會做成幾多生命財產同埋經濟損失。

下面係FT原文

How will the higher risk of mortality affect individuals?

The central estimate is that B.1.1.7 carries a 30 to 40 per cent higher chance of dying. The impact of this relative risk on an individual will depend critically on his or her absolute risk — determined above all by age and then by underlying health and other factors. The evidence considered by Nervtag suggests that the variant increases case fatality rates consistently across all age groups.

Sir Patrick took men in their 60s as an example. The average risk was that about 10 in every 1,000 would be expected to die from the infection with the old virus; with the new variant, 13 or 14 would die.

For healthy children and young adults, who are extremely unlikely to die from Covid-19, the additional lethality of B.1.1.7 would have a tiny effect on their absolute risk. Conversely, it would have a big impact on people over 80 who were already at high risk.

It is worth remembering that fatality rates are already considerably lower than they were in the first wave of the pandemic in the spring, because health workers have learned how best to treat Covid-19 patients, including when to give dexamethasone steroid to those who are severely ill. Even if the new variant raises risk of death by 35 per cent, it would still be lower than for someone with the original form of the virus back in March.

下面係FT原文

How will the higher risk of mortality affect individuals?

The central estimate is that B.1.1.7 carries a 30 to 40 per cent higher chance of dying. The impact of this relative risk on an individual will depend critically on his or her absolute risk — determined above all by age and then by underlying health and other factors. The evidence considered by Nervtag suggests that the variant increases case fatality rates consistently across all age groups.

Sir Patrick took men in their 60s as an example. The average risk was that about 10 in every 1,000 would be expected to die from the infection with the old virus; with the new variant, 13 or 14 would die.

For healthy children and young adults, who are extremely unlikely to die from Covid-19, the additional lethality of B.1.1.7 would have a tiny effect on their absolute risk. Conversely, it would have a big impact on people over 80 who were already at high risk.

It is worth remembering that fatality rates are already considerably lower than they were in the first wave of the pandemic in the spring, because health workers have learned how best to treat Covid-19 patients, including when to give dexamethasone steroid to those who are severely ill. Even if the new variant raises risk of death by 35 per cent, it would still be lower than for someone with the original form of the virus back in March.

Source FT

樓上d 精神病人咁中意quote d 呃funding 嘅科學家

嘈乜柒

原來熱狗除左精神病之外，仲唔識英文🤯🤯🤯

下面係FT原文

How will the higher risk of mortality affect individuals?

The central estimate is that B.1.1.7 carries a 30 to 40 per cent higher chance of dying. The impact of this relative risk on an individual will depend critically on his or her absolute risk — determined above all by age and then by underlying health and other factors. The evidence considered by Nervtag suggests that the variant increases case fatality rates consistently across all age groups.

Sir Patrick took men in their 60s as an example. The average risk was that about 10 in every 1,000 would be expected to die from the infection with the old virus; with the new variant, 13 or 14 would die.

For healthy children and young adults, who are extremely unlikely to die from Covid-19, the additional lethality of B.1.1.7 would have a tiny effect on their absolute risk. Conversely, it would have a big impact on people over 80 who were already at high risk.

It is worth remembering that fatality rates are already considerably lower than they were in the first wave of the pandemic in the spring, because health workers have learned how best to treat Covid-19 patients, including when to give dexamethasone steroid to those who are severely ill. Even if the new variant raises risk of death by 35 per cent, it would still be lower than for someone with the original form of the virus back in March.

How will the higher risk of mortality affect individuals?

The central estimate is that B.1.1.7 carries a 30 to 40 per cent higher chance of dying. The impact of this relative risk on an individual will depend critically on his or her absolute risk — determined above all by age and then by underlying health and other factors. The evidence considered by Nervtag suggests that the variant increases case fatality rates consistently across all age groups.

Sir Patrick took men in their 60s as an example. The average risk was that about 10 in every 1,000 would be expected to die from the infection with the old virus; with the new variant, 13 or 14 would die.

For healthy children and young adults, who are extremely unlikely to die from Covid-19, the additional lethality of B.1.1.7 would have a tiny effect on their absolute risk. Conversely, it would have a big impact on people over 80 who were already at high risk.

It is worth remembering that fatality rates are already considerably lower than they were in the first wave of the pandemic in the spring, because health workers have learned how best to treat Covid-19 patients, including when to give dexamethasone steroid to those who are severely ill. Even if the new variant raises risk of death by 35 per cent, it would still be lower than for someone with the original form of the virus back in March.

How will the higher risk of mortality affect individuals?

The central estimate is that B.1.1.7 carries a 30 to 40 per cent higher chance of dying. The impact of this relative risk on an individual will depend critically on his or her absolute risk — determined above all by age and then by underlying health and other factors. The evidence considered by Nervtag suggests that the variant increases case fatality rates consistently across all age groups.

Sir Patrick took men in their 60s as an example. The average risk was that about 10 in every 1,000 would be expected to die from the infection with the old virus; with the new variant, 13 or 14 would die.

For healthy children and young adults, who are extremely unlikely to die from Covid-19, the additional lethality of B.1.1.7 would have a tiny effect on their absolute risk. Conversely, it would have a big impact on people over 80 who were already at high risk.

It is worth remembering that fatality rates are already considerably lower than they were in the first wave of the pandemic in the spring, because health workers have learned how best to treat Covid-19 patients, including when to give dexamethasone steroid to those who are severely ill. Even if the new variant raises risk of death by 35 per cent, it would still be lower than for someone with the original form of the virus back in March.

係，文章入面有數據證明左

無否定過，而樓主亦無講過呢點，做乜要離題？

而且你睇返我上面嗰啲嘢應該都大約知道 我講過話要睇埋幾耐死亡 感染直至到死亡期間 可以傳染到幾大範圍

你覺唔覺你講野好自相矛盾？你唔認同傳播率高都可以死亡率高，但又提出幾耐死亡影響傳播率。感染幾耐先死亡影響傳播率，正正反映傳播率高都可以死亡率高。死亡率高無人話會即刻死

如你所謂話係英國變種咗嗰一隻COVID 19 首先報道話死亡率比之前高咗 係話有其他因素影響佢嘅死亡率


樓主開post 果陣係12月，果陣英國變種出左數據話傳播率高左30%，佢就一口咬定變種只會令到病毒毒性更低，死亡率低。簡單講變種令病毒變弱。

而家篇文章講左英國果隻變種令病毒變強，即係樓主講法係錯。但你就混埋其他野去講。而家死亡率低並唔係病毒變弱，而係醫生識得去醫人。

Ok你話佢變種到傳染率大左 死亡率大左 冇問題㗎 佢進化到咁樣 前提只要佢 傳染率永遠大大領先過死亡率嘅話 比例差好遠就冇影響 佢都係一隻成功嘅病毒 你上網睇吓英國嘅數據 有咩咁難明

下面係FT原文

How will the higher risk of mortality affect individuals?

The central estimate is that B.1.1.7 carries a 30 to 40 per cent higher chance of dying. The impact of this relative risk on an individual will depend critically on his or her absolute risk — determined above all by age and then by underlying health and other factors. The evidence considered by Nervtag suggests that the variant increases case fatality rates consistently across all age groups.

Sir Patrick took men in their 60s as an example. The average risk was that about 10 in every 1,000 would be expected to die from the infection with the old virus; with the new variant, 13 or 14 would die.

For healthy children and young adults, who are extremely unlikely to die from Covid-19, the additional lethality of B.1.1.7 would have a tiny effect on their absolute risk. Conversely, it would have a big impact on people over 80 who were already at high risk.

It is worth remembering that fatality rates are already considerably lower than they were in the first wave of the pandemic in the spring, because health workers have learned how best to treat Covid-19 patients, including when to give dexamethasone steroid to those who are severely ill. Even if the new variant raises risk of death by 35 per cent, it would still be lower than for someone with the original form of the virus back in March.

下面係FT原文

How will the higher risk of mortality affect individuals?

The central estimate is that B.1.1.7 carries a 30 to 40 per cent higher chance of dying. The impact of this relative risk on an individual will depend critically on his or her absolute risk — determined above all by age and then by underlying health and other factors. The evidence considered by Nervtag suggests that the variant increases case fatality rates consistently across all age groups.

Sir Patrick took men in their 60s as an example. The average risk was that about 10 in every 1,000 would be expected to die from the infection with the old virus; with the new variant, 13 or 14 would die.

For healthy children and young adults, who are extremely unlikely to die from Covid-19, the additional lethality of B.1.1.7 would have a tiny effect on their absolute risk. Conversely, it would have a big impact on people over 80 who were already at high risk.

It is worth remembering that fatality rates are already considerably lower than they were in the first wave of the pandemic in the spring, because health workers have learned how best to treat Covid-19 patients, including when to give dexamethasone steroid to those who are severely ill. Even if the new variant raises risk of death by 35 per cent, it would still be lower than for someone with the original form of the virus back in March.

下面係FT原文

How will the higher risk of mortality affect individuals?

The central estimate is that B.1.1.7 carries a 30 to 40 per cent higher chance of dying. The impact of this relative risk on an individual will depend critically on his or her absolute risk — determined above all by age and then by underlying health and other factors. The evidence considered by Nervtag suggests that the variant increases case fatality rates consistently across all age groups.

Sir Patrick took men in their 60s as an example. The average risk was that about 10 in every 1,000 would be expected to die from the infection with the old virus; with the new variant, 13 or 14 would die.

For healthy children and young adults, who are extremely unlikely to die from Covid-19, the additional lethality of B.1.1.7 would have a tiny effect on their absolute risk. Conversely, it would have a big impact on people over 80 who were already at high risk.

It is worth remembering that fatality rates are already considerably lower than they were in the first wave of the pandemic in the spring, because health workers have learned how best to treat Covid-19 patients, including when to give dexamethasone steroid to those who are severely ill. Even if the new variant raises risk of death by 35 per cent, it would still be lower than for someone with the original form of the virus back in March.

replies.msg:
學習英文，幼稚園教ABC，博士課程都一樣用ABC。

所有基礎觀念都係高中教，
大學教進階課程，但唔會違反基礎概念，除非有超前突破性研究發現，推翻基礎觀念，但初高中課程會跟住修改。

香港分文理商科，
意味全港有3分2人缺乏基礎生物學觀念，
而中四不選理科，舊制中六不選生物組的學生，很多很多學生，早就將原來曾讀過的初中生物科，忘記得一乾二淨。


此外AL理科課程也分純數組和生物組，
意味全港懂基礎高中程度的生物學的觀念，
係非常非常少，包括答主。

早前外國有電視台，做左個另類百萬富翁節目，叫「Are you smarter than 5th grader」，也有另一個節目叫「Are you smarter than a ten years old」，邀請公眾上電視台答小五題目，答中15題對，有100萬現金，但結果極少人拿到百萬獎金。

2020年TVB仲誇張，直情請準港姐答小學數學題，都答唔到。

答主雖有物理學底，但對生物及認知心理學，就缺乏基礎知識了。其實大多數人都無或忘記了中一生物學知識，電視台派100萬叫人答返小學題都無人拿到獎。

你講「攞d中一生物學出黎，不如縮返老母個閪先」反映答主對認知科學的無知。
又一個對事實視而不見嘅人

replies.msg:
初中程度生物學會話病毒會向低殺傷力演化，因為咁先會keep住繁殖
但問題係初中學既唔係全貌（任何學科都係：中學物理會教你F=ma但唔會同你講有樣野叫相對論，指出F=ma係高速情況會錯）
病毒係隨機突變，statistically佢地會向低殺傷力演化，因為咁樣佢地存活機率會高d，不過佢地無得「選擇變得低殺傷力」從而令自己存活
所以唔等於唔能夠變得高殺傷力
而點解佢地係隨機突變，可以點樣突變etc.呢d就唔係初中會學既野
所以中一程度生物學講病毒演化(或者任何其他生物既演化)=戇鳩

同埋咁明關認知心理學咩事

學習英文，幼稚園教ABC，博士課程都一樣用ABC。

所有基礎觀念都係高中教，
大學教進階課程，但唔會違反基礎概念，除非有超前突破性研究發現，推翻基礎觀念，但初高中課程會跟住修改。

香港分文理商科，
意味全港有3分2人缺乏基礎生物學觀念，
而中四不選理科，舊制中六不選生物組的學生，很多很多學生，早就將原來曾讀過的初中生物科，忘記得一乾二淨。


此外AL理科課程也分純數組和生物組，
意味全港懂基礎高中程度的生物學的觀念，
係非常非常少，包括答主。

早前外國有電視台，做左個另類百萬富翁節目，叫「Are you smarter than 5th grader」，也有另一個節目叫「Are you smarter than a ten years old」，邀請公眾上電視台答小五題目，答中15題對，有100萬現金，但結果極少人拿到百萬獎金。

2020年TVB仲誇張，直情請準港姐答小學數學題，都答唔到。

答主雖有物理學底，但對生物及認知心理學，就缺乏基礎知識了。其實大多數人都無或忘記了中一生物學知識，電視台派100萬叫人答返小學題都無人拿到獎。

你講「攞d中一生物學出黎，不如縮返老母個閪先」反映答主對認知科學的無知。

下面係FT原文

How will the higher risk of mortality affect individuals?

The central estimate is that B.1.1.7 carries a 30 to 40 per cent higher chance of dying. The impact of this relative risk on an individual will depend critically on his or her absolute risk — determined above all by age and then by underlying health and other factors. The evidence considered by Nervtag suggests that the variant increases case fatality rates consistently across all age groups.

Sir Patrick took men in their 60s as an example. The average risk was that about 10 in every 1,000 would be expected to die from the infection with the old virus; with the new variant, 13 or 14 would die.

For healthy children and young adults, who are extremely unlikely to die from Covid-19, the additional lethality of B.1.1.7 would have a tiny effect on their absolute risk. Conversely, it would have a big impact on people over 80 who were already at high risk.

It is worth remembering that fatality rates are already considerably lower than they were in the first wave of the pandemic in the spring, because health workers have learned how best to treat Covid-19 patients, including when to give dexamethasone steroid to those who are severely ill. Even if the new variant raises risk of death by 35 per cent, it would still be lower than for someone with the original form of the virus back in March.

How will the higher risk of mortality affect individuals?

The central estimate is that B.1.1.7 carries a 30 to 40 per cent higher chance of dying. The impact of this relative risk on an individual will depend critically on his or her absolute risk — determined above all by age and then by underlying health and other factors. The evidence considered by Nervtag suggests that the variant increases case fatality rates consistently across all age groups.

Sir Patrick took men in their 60s as an example. The average risk was that about 10 in every 1,000 would be expected to die from the infection with the old virus; with the new variant, 13 or 14 would die.

For healthy children and young adults, who are extremely unlikely to die from Covid-19, the additional lethality of B.1.1.7 would have a tiny effect on their absolute risk. Conversely, it would have a big impact on people over 80 who were already at high risk.

It is worth remembering that fatality rates are already considerably lower than they were in the first wave of the pandemic in the spring, because health workers have learned how best to treat Covid-19 patients, including when to give dexamethasone steroid to those who are severely ill. Even if the new variant raises risk of death by 35 per cent, it would still be lower than for someone with the original form of the virus back in March.

How will the higher risk of mortality affect individuals?

The central estimate is that B.1.1.7 carries a 30 to 40 per cent higher chance of dying. The impact of this relative risk on an individual will depend critically on his or her absolute risk — determined above all by age and then by underlying health and other factors. The evidence considered by Nervtag suggests that the variant increases case fatality rates consistently across all age groups.

Sir Patrick took men in their 60s as an example. The average risk was that about 10 in every 1,000 would be expected to die from the infection with the old virus; with the new variant, 13 or 14 would die.

For healthy children and young adults, who are extremely unlikely to die from Covid-19, the additional lethality of B.1.1.7 would have a tiny effect on their absolute risk. Conversely, it would have a big impact on people over 80 who were already at high risk.

It is worth remembering that fatality rates are already considerably lower than they were in the first wave of the pandemic in the spring, because health workers have learned how best to treat Covid-19 patients, including when to give dexamethasone steroid to those who are severely ill. Even if the new variant raises risk of death by 35 per cent, it would still be lower than for someone with the original form of the virus back in March.

下面係FT原文

How will the higher risk of mortality affect individuals?

The central estimate is that B.1.1.7 carries a 30 to 40 per cent higher chance of dying. The impact of this relative risk on an individual will depend critically on his or her absolute risk — determined above all by age and then by underlying health and other factors. The evidence considered by Nervtag suggests that the variant increases case fatality rates consistently across all age groups.

Sir Patrick took men in their 60s as an example. The average risk was that about 10 in every 1,000 would be expected to die from the infection with the old virus; with the new variant, 13 or 14 would die.

For healthy children and young adults, who are extremely unlikely to die from Covid-19, the additional lethality of B.1.1.7 would have a tiny effect on their absolute risk. Conversely, it would have a big impact on people over 80 who were already at high risk.

It is worth remembering that fatality rates are already considerably lower than they were in the first wave of the pandemic in the spring, because health workers have learned how best to treat Covid-19 patients, including when to give dexamethasone steroid to those who are severely ill. Even if the new variant raises risk of death by 35 per cent, it would still be lower than for someone with the original form of the virus back in March.
